post: I hate meetings. So we don’t have any at WebVeda.com! Throughout my career, I’ve been in countless meetings that could’ve been emails — no clear agenda, no value added. Time wasted that could be better spent working. So when I started up again, I decided not to have calls unless absolutely necessary. Every Monday, the team connects for company updates. Everything else happens async — through email and tools like Asana. When we do have a call, it’s done in 15 minutes, leaving time for banter and fun! The principle is simple: plan well, respect everyone’s time, and document everything. That’s how we protect what truly matters — our focus.

This story is going to change the way you think.

There were two brothers, both raised by an alcoholic father.

One grew up to be an alcoholic.
When asked what happened, he said:
"I watched my father."

The other grew up and never touched alcohol.
When asked why, he said:
"I watched my father."

Your perspective is your greatest advantage or your biggest limitation.

You can't always control what happens to you, but you can always decide what to learn from it.

Ask yourself:

- What lesson am I choosing to see in this challenge?
- How can this experience shape me, and not break me?

Your perspective will determine your future.
Make sure it shapes you into the person you are meant to be.

Every day, you face hundreds of small decisions:

Emails to reply to.
Requests to handle.
Messages that need attention.

More than time, it’s the overwhelm that slows you down.

The 4-Part Clarity Framework helps you filter every task, message, or request into one of four actions:

- Archive
- Reply
- Forward
- Compose

Once you start working this way, the noise disappears.
Try it for a week and watch how much lighter your days feel.

Which of the 4 do you think you need to do more of?

Not everything important is urgent.
To cut the noise and focus better, I use the Eisenhower Matrix:

- Do what’s urgent AND important.
This drives results.

- Delegate what’s urgent, but NOT important.
Pass them on. Your time is better spent elsewhere. Extremely accessible now thanks to AI.

- Schedule what’s important, but NOT urgent.
No matter how busy you are, protect time for this.
It moves you forward long-term.

- Eliminate what’s NEITHER urgent NOR important.
This wastes your energy.

Constant responsiveness creates the illusion of progress while stealing time from the work that actually moves us forward.

If everything feels urgent, it’s usually because priorities aren’t clear.
And when priorities aren’t clear, urgency fills the gap.

The goal isn’t to do everything faster.
It’s to decide what deserves your attention before the day begins.

When you’re 20, you care about what everyone thinks.
When you're 40, you stop caring about what everyone thinks.
When you're 60, you realize no one was ever thinking about you in the first place.

We waste years living under an invisible spotlight.

We hesitate to post that idea, start that project, or make that change.
Even if we’re more capable than everyone else. 
Why? Because we’re afraid of being judged.

Most people are too caught up in their own lives to think about ours for long.
They’ll scroll past, move on, and forget.
While we’re still holding back.

Try one of these this week:

- Post the idea you’ve been sitting on.
- Pitch the project even if it’s not “perfect.”
- Say the thing that’s real instead of what’s safe.
- Try and fail publicly. Most people won’t even try privately.

Every day you delay out of fear, you reinforce the idea that someone else’s opinion matters more than your potential.

It doesn’t.
It never did.

Do the thing.
Be seen doing it.
Let them watch (or not).

You exist for yourself. Not to perform for them.

Everyone talks about the importance of a mentor.
But how do you know if it’s the right mentor?
And how do you seek their time?

First — 3 signs of a good mentor:

1. The mentor should NOT be the only one you have.

One person can't take care of everything.
You need to have multiple mentors catering to fields they can help with.
For example, I have different mentors for money, career, spirituality, people management, etc.

2. The mentor should NOT be much older than you.

When 20-year-olds write to me requesting for me to become their mentor, I have a facepalm moment.
I will make a horrible mentor to a 20-year-old.
Because things that are obvious to me are things the other person would not have even experienced (for no fault of theirs).

What you want is a mentor who is 5-10 years older than you.
So that they offer a relatable perspective.

3. The mentor should NOT think like you.

If they do, you will get the same answers that you too would have come up with.
The mentor needs to challenge your thinking; ask you questions to push you in a new direction that you could explore.

Second — once you identify who that person can be, simply ask:

- Send cold emails
- Request them for an hour a month
- Be clear about what you want from them in that hour, and update them on your progress.

As long as you are not looking for a celebrity as your mentor, you will be surprised by how many people will find the time and space to help you.

You’re in a team meeting, and you want to share your point. But everyone’s talking, and no one is listening.

Here’s a strategy that I’ve seen work effectively: The Speak-Last Advantage.

Simon Sinek once said that the people who speak later in discussions (after listening and observing others) are perceived as more thoughtful and credible.

- It gives everybody else the feeling that they have been heard.
- You get the benefit of hearing what everybody else has to think before you share your opinion.

Try this in your next meeting:

Let others go first. Take notes. Listen for gaps or insights they’ve missed. Then summarise, add value, and connect the dots.

You’ll notice people start paying attention. Because you spoke when it mattered.

If you don’t control your time, someone else will.

7 time management frameworks to own your time:

1) Measuring my time
At the age of 14, I started preparing for engineering exams, only to realise I just could not manage my time. So I recorded every hour of my day; I did this for 13 years. Just this act of measurement led to the act of improvement. Do it for 10 days and you will see the difference.

2) Time blocking
I realised context switching was taking a toll. I started blocking 2-3 hours and have been doing so till date. Monday AM: X, Monday PM: Y, Tuesday all day: Z

3) Win the week, not the day
Think of your week as your time unit, not your day. Think of what you wish to achieve in a week and split your week to achieve that.

4) Single source of action
We are constantly being fed a to-do list from multiple sources. What helps me is to have a single source of action - my emails. It can be a to-do app for you, a notebook, or post-its - anything except your memory.

5) Create repeatable tasks
I am a student of processes. So my endeavour is - find something I need to do in life, and find a way to convert it into a recurring task which I can add to my calendar. It builds a habit, routine, and discipline for your mind.

6) Setup distraction time
Our mind craves distraction because we make it a forbidden fruit. Do the opposite. Set up time to waste time.

7) Zoom out
We struggle to manage time because we look at it in a micro way. Go back to the macro. What do you want to achieve this month, quarter, or year? What are the big milestones that will get you there (or tell you that you are on the path)? Did that happen this week? If yes - great. If not - go back to step 1 and figure out what went wrong. Repeat every week.

3 things we take for granted (until life reminds us how lucky we truly are):

1. The people who remind you who you are when you forget
The mentor who challenges you. The friend who listens without judgment. The manager who believes in you even when you’re doubting yourself. They’re the reason you keep growing.

2. The work that challenges you
Some days it feels like you’re barely keeping up. The goals keep moving, the expectations keep rising. And you wonder if you’re doing enough. But that same work is teaching you how capable you really are. You’re learning to trust your judgment, to speak up, and to back yourself even if no one else does.

3. The stability that lets you dream
It’s hard to think long-term when you’re worried about next month’s bills. If your career gives you stability — enough to plan, to rest, to imagine what’s next — that’s something to be grateful for. It’s the invisible foundation most ambition is built on.

I used to think getting rich was about how much you earn. Until I read The Psychology of Money, and these 5 lessons changed my mindset:

1. Being rich is NOT being wealthy. Whenever you go to someone's lavish house, you will always think: 'Wow! What a magnificent & spacious house.' Never: 'Wow! What a massive loan they might have on their head.' We think being rich = things people have that we can see. Being wealthy means you earn without spending your time.

2. Controlling your time is the biggest wealth. If you are earning money for the sake of earning money & spending it on lavish things, you're running on a lifelong treadmill. But if you earn money with the motivation of buying more time, That will be the true value of money. That will set you free.

3. Generate luck as a discipline in life. Let's say you write 100 cold emails per day, for a freelance gig. Let's assume that you get 5 replies out of 100. In this case, you're increasing your odds of getting lucky everyday. Because one day, there will be a reply which can change your life.

4. Compounding is the 8th wonder of the world. Small changes in one direction make a huge difference over a long period of time. This is not just for your investments. It also applies to organisations, relationships, and personal abilities.

5. Money is not important if you can't sleep at night. What's the point of having crores in your bank, if you are not able to sleep? Or what's the point of investing in risky instruments that keep you up at night? No amount of money is worth more than your sleep.

“I hate my job. But I love the financial stability that it brings. What should I do?” I recently got this as an email from a reader.

Here’s how to deal with it:

You have financial stability right now. Do not dismiss it. That stability is important.

Now, become obsessive about your time. Do your work diligently, but spare as much time as you can after that to explore. Your nights, weekends, holidays — whatever you can manage. Explore different things that you feel you could be good at.

Most of us do it wrong: We quit our jobs. Put the pressure on a new path to make us money. When it is way too early to be monetised.

Enjoy the exploration. Refine your skills and knowledge over time.

Because here’s the thing: When you find something you truly enjoy and are good at, You will eventually find a way to make money from it. Which is when you can say no to your job.

Stability gives you the freedom to explore, if you use it wisely. Play the long game, and one day, your curiosity will pay your bills!

Everyone talks about cracking interviews. But how do you deal with interview rejections?

A lot of people reach out to me seeking help on this. Here’s what I’d suggest:

1. Don’t take it personally.
Companies have certain criteria (skillset or cultural fit) while looking for hires, and they hold no personal grudge against you.

2. Write a thank you email.
No agenda. Simply being grateful for what you learnt and thanking the hiring manager for their time. This small act makes you stand out — very few candidates do it.

3. Ask for feedback.
If you want to learn from the experience, seek permission for feedback. Do it a few days later, not immediately after the rejection.
Immediately = you look desperate for the job.
Later = you look like someone genuinely committed to growth.

4. Reflect on the process yourself.
Note down:
- What questions did you struggle with?
- Where did your confidence dip?
- Which answers could you refine for next time?

Rejections hurt — but if you look beyond the “no”, you learn something that brings you closer to the “yes.”

Go back to the day you first rode a bicycle or drove a car. You faltered. You stumbled. Maybe you were embarrassed of yourself.

But today? You ride/drive like a pro!

Listening to music. Chatting with your friends. While driving/riding.

Because you showed up again the next day and did that task repeatedly.

The exact same way you deal with failure or things not going as per plan too.

Failure is a muscle. It's a muscle that you build over time. And ironically, the only way to build failure as a muscle is to fail.

Fail every day.

Do something that scares you, that challenges you, that you are intimidated by. Where the cost of failing is very low.

Say good morning and smile at somebody who is a complete stranger in the elevator. Go and ask your boss for a favour that you know they will refuse.

If you put yourself in that spot often enough, you’ll be surprised how these small failures make you more comfortable with the ‘real’ ones when they arrive.

Because here's the truth.

Everybody in this world will fail. The difference is not whether we will fail or not.

The difference is how we pick ourselves up once we have failed. Because that paves the path for success.

What if the best networking strategy had nothing to do with “networking” at all?

Back in 2014, I started a group called “Delhi Internet Mafia” to learn from and share insights with founders based out of Delhi. I would cold email founders to show up for the catchup. Vijay Shekhar Sharma of Paytm showed up for one of them.

I remember being blown away by his energy, his ambition and his clarity. We stayed in touch. A few years later, Paytm invested in my startup nearbuy.

If it weren’t for that group, we may have never raised money from Paytm.

3 ways to build genuine relationships:

1/ Do not try to impress. Be impressed.
People can see through your attempts to impress them. But what people can truly be attracted to is your interest in them. Genuine interest.

2/ Engage meaningfully.
If engaging offline, ask questions out of pure curiosity to truly understand. If engaging online, don’t just comment “Great post!” — add insight or ask smart questions.

3/ Give before you ask.
That could be sharing feedback on their work, amplifying their content, or connecting them to someone useful.

You can never fail with authenticity and trust.

Risk and failure DO NOT exist. They are states of mind.

For most of us reading this — thanks to our upbringing, education, exposure, and privilege — survival isn’t a concern for us.

None of us, irrespective of how hard we fall, will ever find ourselves on the streets. None of us is ever going to die of hunger or poverty.

Us and our parents have worked hard to get to this point.

No matter what we bet with our time and effort, our losses are capped. But our wins are not.

We could lose 99 times. But the 1 time we win (and we eventually shall), that win could change everything.

We can win with no limits.

What stops us is the failure in our head.

That of losing face. That of losing status. That of losing our standing.

We created it. So we can destroy it too.

The only true failure is not taking your chance at all, least of all for the sake of others’ opinions.

"I think I romanticized the idea of a break."

Early 20s. Bright student. Worked 4 years in a challenging but intellectually stimulating environment. Quit to take a break.

4 months into it. Now, not doing so well. Finds it hard to take action. Binge watches.

This was my exact reply to my mentee:

"I am not an expert, so most of what I share comes from secondary research and not primary experience or agency.

Your mind is currently your enemy. It thinks of everything possible. What went wrong. What could go wrong.

You are in a state of constant mental activity, but no action. You need to convert that into a state of action - no matter how imperfect it is.

Here is what I would do:

1. Get my bloodwork done. Find my deficiencies. And through diet and supplements, fill those.

2. Remove all options in life. No savings, no family, or friends. You have 2 months. Assume all your money and network runs out. Put yourself into a spot where your mind isn't thinking, "Oh I have time, let's take more time." It should be thinking, "There is no time to think. Just execute."

3. Everyday - just act. Start working out. Start stepping out. Take decisions within 5 seconds. Even if it's wrong. The ones that go really wrong - you will spend time correcting them. Get intellectually busy!

4. Delete all apps that numb you. They are not your friends. They are simply entertaining you; not educating you. When you feel withdrawal, go for a walk.

The only thing that makes humans feel alive is a sense of action; a sense of progress. Get out of your head. And act!"

I received this email recently:

A woman had trouble sleeping. Couldn’t shut down the brain.

Tried acknowledging her emotions and speaking to her family. But couldn’t figure out what was keeping her up.

I asked her, “What usually occupies your mind?”

“Job search, loan, shaadi related talks, where to settle conversations - move back to India or stay in the States a little longer. It's hard to pick priorities in life because we have limited time like personal health, career, mental peace or good money."

To which I replied:

“You are worried because you want everything in your control. And you want everything to work out. And you want every person who knows you to be happy with what you do.

But the reality is:

1. You control only a small part of your life. Realising this sets you free.

2. Everything will not work out. And is not meant to work out. Life is the sum of small things that work out, not one big thing that works out.

3. People, just like you do, react to the moment. They cannot always see beyond the moment. So it's possible that in the moment, they will be unhappy, disappointed, angry. But that doesn't mean they will always remain that way.

Set yourself free. Life is not a perfect picture that needs to get clicked in one go. Life is a jigsaw puzzle of that same perfect image. You have to fit the pieces one by one.

You won't get it right the first time. But you will get it right eventually.”

27th Aug 2002 - I took my first ever flight in my life. To the US.

Papa had had to take a Rs. 55,000 loan to pay for the one-way ticket.

I still remember the scene at the Delhi airport. My entire family had come to see me off. Everyone was crying. I was crying too.

But I was also excited. This is what I had always dreamt of.

To go to the US for a fine education, become a space scientist, join NASA, land on Mars. That dream was finally coming true.

Until I realised midway through the program, this was something I was good at. But not something I liked. I dropped out, and it felt like my world had come to an end.

27th August 2022 - exactly 20 years to the day I left for Michigan State, the university confirmed me as a speaker for their alumni speaker series.

When I came back to India, if someone had come up to me and said:

“Hey - I am from the future. And I have some exciting news for you. In about 2 decades, you will have more than 15M+ people following you on something really cool called social media. You would have written four best selling books. You will be invited by top companies to address their employees and motivate them. Forget all of that - this very university that you are dropping out from, will call you back to address their students.”

I would have told the person to get a CT Scan :))

But here I am, living this life. Not because I am the smartest person I know or the most hard working person I know. I am living this life because I did not give up on myself.

A lot of you would be going through something similar in your lives. A new company, a new city, a new career, a new relationship, a new experience. And it may not always turn out to be what you wanted it to be.

But that's not the end. There is never any end, until the day we all die.

Up until that day, you have yourself. And I wish for you to find that yourself one day.

Intelligence is not about having all the right answers.

Because answers change. Situations change. The world changes.

What matters more is adaptability.

3 ways to build adaptability:

- Question assumptions

Don’t just accept “this is how it’s always done.” Ask what’s changed and what could be done differently.

- Experiment small, adjust fast

Run quick tests instead of big bets. Adaptation is easier when the cost of failure is low.

- Watch patterns, not events

One failure or success doesn’t tell the whole story. Look for trends before you decide how to adjust.

The real test comes when we are forced out of our comfort zones.

When the job we thought we’d stay in forever disappears. When the skills we worked so hard to learn become outdated. When the life plan we once imagined no longer makes sense.

In those moments, the smartest person in the room is not the one who knows the most.

It is the one who adapts the fastest.

Our minds are brilliant at one thing:
Proving ourselves right.

But most people use this ability against themselves.
They reinforce doubts, fears, and limitations.

Say it enough times, and your brain will gladly back you up.
Show you enough proof to convince you that you are not good enough.

But the same mechanism can work for you!

If you learn to direct your focus, reframe your questions, and shift your self-talk, your brain becomes your ally.

- Ask: What would this look like if it were easy?

- Replace “I can’t” with “How can I?”

- Focus on effort over outcome - What did I learn? What can I try next?

The mind is powerful and programmable.
Use it wisely.

If you’ve taken the first step, congratulations.

You’ve already beaten the “ifs and buts” that keep most people stuck.

But the real challenge?

When the excitement fades.
When results don’t show up quickly.

5 ways to keep going when motivation runs out:

1. Measure your progress by inputs, not outcome
You can’t control the outcome. But you can control your inputs.
And that’s what you need to feel in control.

2. 2-minute rule
Make it ridiculously easy for you to keep doing it - especially on the days you don’t feel like it.
Do it for 2 minutes every day, until you start getting used to it.

3. Temptation bundling
Bundle what you like to do and what you want to do as part of a routine.
For example: You like watching YouTube, but you want to have an upskill routine.
So, you could watch your course content on YouTube — tutorials, discussions, animations, etc.

4. Habit stacking (from Atomic Habits)
Combine the new activity you want to incorporate before or after an existing habit.
This way, there’s less friction and it blends into your routine.

5. What if?
Close your eyes and visualise what will happen if you are unable to pursue this.
More importantly, if you do – how will it change your life?

The only thing that makes humans feel alive is a sense of action.
Not overthinking!
